articles.headline: A Knife Sheath, Phone Pings and Trash: The Hunt for a Killer in Idaho
articles.snippet: On the night four college students were killed, a roommate saw a man clad in black walk through the home. It took a cross-country investigation to find a suspect.
articles.abstract: On the night four college students were killed, a roommate saw a man clad in black walk through the home. It took a cross-country investigation to find a suspect.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Idaho — On the night in November when four University of Idaho students were murdered in a home near campus, another roommate awoke to a noise that she thought was her friend playing with her dog. Then she heard someone crying, and a man saying something like, “It’s OK, I’m going to help you.”
articles.byline: By Mike Baker, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Serge F. Kovaleski

articles.headline: Church Lays Benedict to Rest, if Not Its Divisions
articles.snippet: An extraordinary period for the modern church ended with Francis presiding over the funeral of his retired predecessor. Some conservatives found the ceremony too modest for their standard-bearer.
articles.abstract: An extraordinary period for the modern church ended with Francis presiding over the funeral of his retired predecessor. Some conservatives found the ceremony too modest for their standard-bearer.
articles.lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — The Roman Catholic Church on Thursday laid to rest Pope Emeritus Benedict XVI in front of a fog-shrouded St. Peter’s Basilica with an extraordinary funeral presided over by his own successor, Francis, a final peculiarity to end a strange era in the modern church in which two popes, one resigned and one in power, one conservative and one liberal, coexisted in the tiny confines of the Vatican.

articles.headline: Even a Soft Landing for the Economy May Be Uneven
articles.snippet: Small businesses and lower-income families could feel pinched in the months ahead whether or not a recession is avoided this year.
articles.abstract: Small businesses and lower-income families could feel pinched in the months ahead whether or not a recession is avoided this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the defining economic stories of the past year was the complex debate over whether the U.S. economy was going into a recession or merely descending, with some altitude sickness, from a peak in growth after pandemic lows.

articles.headline: Speaker Quest Reveals McCarthy’s Tenuous Grip on an Unruly Majority
articles.snippet: As the Republican leader has made concessions to the far right, he has effectively agreed to give them carte blanche to disrupt the workings of the House — and to hold him hostage to their demands.
articles.abstract: As the Republican leader has made concessions to the far right, he has effectively agreed to give them carte blanche to disrupt the workings of the House — and to hold him hostage to their demands.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Kevin McCarthy’s historically long slog to become speaker of the House has made one thing abundantly clear: The United States should brace for the likelihood of a Congress in perpetual disarray for the next two years.

articles.headline: McCarthy Wins Speakership on 15th Vote After Concessions to Hard Right
articles.snippet: An agreement with ultraconservative Republicans delivered a breakthrough for the California Republican, but he still had to claw his way to the post during a dramatic post-midnight session.
articles.abstract: An agreement with ultraconservative Republicans delivered a breakthrough for the California Republican, but he still had to claw his way to the post during a dramatic post-midnight session.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Kevin McCarthy of California won election early Saturday as House speaker in a historic five-day, 15-ballot floor fight, after giving major concessions to right-wing holdouts and weathering a dramatic late-night setback that underscored the limits of his power over the new Republican majority.

articles.headline: Stranded by Southwest and Stuck With Unexpected Costs
articles.snippet: The airline’s customers incurred thousands in expenses as they scrambled to find alternate ways to get home.
articles.abstract: The airline’s customers incurred thousands in expenses as they scrambled to find alternate ways to get home.
articles.lead_paragraph: Olivia Laskowski was in Nashville and expecting to fly home to New York on Dec. 27 when she received a text message from Southwest Airlines the night before that her flight was canceled. Four days and more than $600 later, Ms. Laskowski and her Siamese cat, Pretzel, were finally back home in Brooklyn.

articles.headline: China’s Covid Surge Threatens Villages as Lunar New Year Approaches
articles.snippet: Millions are expected to travel home this month, spreading Covid to rural communities where health care services are woefully underdeveloped.
articles.abstract: Millions are expected to travel home this month, spreading Covid to rural communities where health care services are woefully underdeveloped.
articles.lead_paragraph: The infections in Dadi Village, a corn farming community tucked between verdant hills in China’s remote southwest, started in early December when a handful of young people returned from jobs in big cities.
articles.byline: By David Pierson, Joy Dong, Claire Fu and Olivia Wang

articles.headline: Southwest’s Meltdown Could Cost It Up to $825 Million
articles.snippet: The airline has not said how soon it will upgrade the systems that contributed to mass flight cancellations, or how much that will cost.
articles.abstract: The airline has not said how soon it will upgrade the systems that contributed to mass flight cancellations, or how much that will cost.
articles.lead_paragraph: The meltdown that forced Southwest Airlines to cancel more than 16,700 holiday flights could cost the carrier between $725 million and $825 million, the airline said in a filing on Friday. The total represents about as much as the airline earned in the first nine months of last year.
articles.byline: By Niraj Chokshi and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: U.S. Added 223,000 Jobs in December, a Slight Easing in Pace
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve’s moves to cool the economy with higher interest rates seem to be taking gentle hold. Wage growth lost momentum.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve’s moves to cool the economy with higher interest rates seem to be taking gentle hold. Wage growth lost momentum.
articles.lead_paragraph: The U.S. economy produced jobs at a slower but still comfortable rate at the end of 2022, as higher interest rates and changing consumer habits downshifted the labor market without bringing it to a halt.
